newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Time decay weighs on dollar volatilities.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Time decay weighs on dollar volatilities.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar-pair options continued sliding in quiet late Friday business as time-decay over a long weekend in the U.S. weighed on the market, dealers said.
With the spot dollar well above critical support levels, activity fizzled out early because U.S. financial markets will be closed on Monday for Labor Day, they said.
"Basically, things have gotten gradually quiet over the course of the day, and volatilities have continued to soften," said a trader at a Canadian bank in Toronto.
One-month implied volatility for dollar/mark was off 0.2 point to 6.55/6.75 percent. One-month dollar/yen dipped to 6.2/6.4 percent from Thursday's 6.3/6.7.

Risk reversals, which measure pricing differential between puts and calls, were steady. One-month 25-delta was at 0.6/0.8 percent in favor of mark calls in dollar/mark and 0.7/1.0 percent in favor of yen calls in dollar/yen.
"This week has been tough because...there wasn't too much liquidity, and everything just settled in where it is," said an interbank broker in New York.
The front end of the volatility curve, around the one-week area, was ruthlessly marked down because of the time decay, although the back end was more or less steadier.
Traders said the spot dollar's rise above 108.50 yen, a longstanding resistance level, to the 108.80 area did not spur interest in options.
Instead, the move seemed to have eased concerns the U.S. unit might have reached a near-term top after a brief rally earlier in the week.

"Spot did tick up above 108.50, which was a little surprising especially in this kind of a market," the interbank broker said. "But once everybody is back in the market, things could settle down and we could go back into a range."

The dollar was slightly weaker in early trade but slowly crept up towards the end of the day as prospects of a Federal Reserve credit tightening by the end of the year got fresh support from a big jump in August Chicago Purchasing Managers index. The index rose to 60.0 in August from 51.2 in July.
Volatilities for the European crosses were also mostly subdued amid uncertainties about the fate of European Monetary Union.

One-month mark/French franc eased slightly to 2.8/3.3 percent, helped by a pull-back in the spot mark ahead of Sunday's meeting between French President Jacques Chirac and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.
